No. F. 7 (30)-R.I|35.—In exercise of the powers conferred by sub-rule (2) of rule 33, rule 37, rule 42, and sub-clause (d) of rule 44 of the Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, the Governor General in Council is pleased to direct that the following further amendment shall be made in the Revised Leave Rules, 1933, namely :— For the proviso to rule 9 of the said Rules the following proviso shall be substituted, namely :— ' Provided that when the earned leave due amounts to— (i) 120 days in the case of an officer in superior service who is entitled to joining time under Fundamental Rule 105 {d) only once in throe or four years ; (n) 90 days in the case of any other officer in superior service ; (m) 30 days in the case of an officer in inferior service ; the officer ceases to earn such leave,' P. NOTIFICATION. Simla, the 11th July 1935. No. F. 6 (25)-R. 1X135.—The following Reso lution by the Secretary of State for India in Council is published for general information :— In exercise of the powers conferred by sub section (2) of Section 96B of the Government of India Act, the Secretary of State, with the con currence of the majority of votes at a meeting of the Council of India held this 18th day of June 1935, hereby makes the following rule, namely :— ' The Governor General in Council and the Local Government of any Governor's Province may, by general or special orders, permit deviations from any provisions of a purely procedural nature contained in any rules made or confirmed under Section 96B of the Government of India Act : provided that such deviations shall not affect the conditions of service, the pay and allowances, or the pensions of officers subject to the rule-making control of the Secretary of State in Council P. C. TALLENTS, Secy, to the Govt, of India. Jjetter to all Local Covemments except the Central provinces, i^o. .376/32-2-Ests., dated the 3rd December 1932. 1 am directed to say that the G-overnment of India have recently had under consideration the question of the modification of the procedure of the Public Service Commission in disciplinary cases with a view to reduce the difficulties that might occur in any individual case in which the conclusions of that body differed from those of a local Government. 2. The disciplinary cases in which the Public Service Commission have not accepted the conclusions of a local Government have been very few. Although in the nature of things the possibilities of differences of opinion in these matters between a local Government and the Commission can never be entirely eliminated, the2. J-) Grovernment of India are disposed to think that the chances of such disagreement can 'be minimised if the Public Service Commission referred 'back to a local G-overnment, through the Grovernment of India, any points regard to in a disciplinary case in/which the evidence appeared to the Commission to 'be insufficient. This should enable a local G-ovemment to examine the case further, hut if any new evidence of facts were 'brought on the record 'by means of such a reference, the /officer concerned would, of course, have to he made acquainted with them and given the opportunity of examining them. Similarly cases would 'be referred 'back if it appeared to the Oommission and the G-overnment of India that the procedure was defective. Such cases would he rare for the Government of India have no doubt that local Governments have issued detailed instructions 'based on the Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules to ensure that the procedure in departmental proceedings is in accordance with the rules and is not open to criticism. -Kven though references on these two points will not he frequent, it appears to the Government of India that this procedure will 'be of value precisely on these comparatively rare occasions when friction is likely to develop 'between the Commission and a local Government They have, therefore, decided to commend it to the Commission for adoption in suitable cases and will watch its working with interest. Copy of a letter No. JJ'. 108/35-S dated the 10th August 1935 from the Secretary, Public Service Commiss ion to the Government of India, Home Department. I am directed to address you on the need of the better observance of the provisions of Rule 55 of theCivil Services I Classification, Control and Appeal) Hules and its counterpart, Hule 34 of the Railway Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, which provide for the holding of departmental inquiries before the infliction of certain penalties on members of the Civil Services. In the Home; Department's circular letter No, 376/32-JSsts., dated the 3rd December 1932, it was assumed that local Governments had issued such detailed instructions based on the Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Eules, as would ensure that the procedure in departmental proceedings was in accordance with the rules. The Commission have reeently found reason to doubt whether that assumption is altogether well founded, 2. As the Government of India are aware, the Public Service Commission have to examine every year a large number of these departmental cases, of which they perhaps see more than any other single inlndia. It is now apparant to the Commission that in not a few cases the proceedings are drawn up not merely in disregard, but almost in ignorance, of the provisions of the Hules cited. Not to mention others, the Commission have been compelled in recent months to return three cases I of which particulars will be given below> for the purpose of rectifying major defects in procedure. 3, In the first of these cases, which involved the question of the removal from the service of an officer of the Indian Police, no actual charge had been framed against the delinquent. In the second, which related to the Railway Department, the officer believed to be at fault was actually punished by an authority which had not the power to do so, while no charge had ever ^0011 fr^niGd against him at all, nor had any inquiry been held into his conduct, beyond the kal*x±Mtmxkiatxm&*K± inquiry into the accident in whichhe was supposed to have played a contrihutory part. In the third case an Inoome-Tax Officer was refused an oral inquirj, although he had made it abundantly clear that he desired one. A fourth case exhibiting an analogous defect has also had to 'be referred hack to the Department concerned, and is still under disposal 'by the Commission. 4. It will 'be observed that in all these cases open disregard was shown for essential provisions of the rules in question to an extent which no advisory 'body in the position of the Public Service Commission could possibly overlook. Apart from the fact that these provisions have been deliberatelt inserted for the protection of the members of the Services, the disregard of them provides an officer who has been punished with an almost irresistible case for the reversal on appeal of any order passed against him. In the matter of defective procedure the Public Service Commission have only one course open to them. Un the other hand, they are conscious that sometimes the objections that they are constrained to take on the above grounds to departmental proceedings are apt to be regarded by departments converned as unsubstantial or technical In their character, and dilatory and vaxatous in their practical effect. While the Commission cannot conceds that there is any justice in these criticisms, they readily recog nise that delay in terminating departmental proceedings must always be prejudicial to good discipline. 5. 1 am to suggest, therefore, that the Home Depart ment should issue a circular letter to the various departments of the Government of India as well as to the Provincial O-overnments, asking that, whereever full instructions as to the proper observance of Bule 55 (Rule 34 of the Railway Rules) have not been issued, this may now be done. The Commission believe that it*4. takes no more time or trouble to draw up proceedings regularly than it does to conduct them irregularly, un the other hand, the due observance ot prescribed procedure helps in the early disposal of cases, and so in the end tends to the 'better maintenance of the rights of 'both Government and its officers, which the purpose that rule 55 and other rules are designed to serve.Ko ,f>L of 19JJ.' New Delhiy the 20th December 1935, S ubject :— Rebate on air passages. Sir, I am directed to invite a reference to the Government of India, Home Department, endorsement No. F. 113/35-Ests., dated the 11th July 1935, regarding the grant of passages by air to officers entitled to passage concessions under Schedule IV to the Superior Civil Services Rules, and to Rule 3 II of the Passage Rules, 1925, and to say that His Majesty's Secretary of State for India has been negotiating for some time past with Imperial Airways, Limited, for the grant of rebate on air passages booked with them which are paid for out of public funds. An arrangement for the grant of this rebate has now been made with that Company and it is set forth in the Memorandum of Procedure accepted by the Secretary of State and Imperial Airways, Limited, and the extract from India Office letter No. S. & G. 2493/35, dated 1st August 1935, which forms an enclosure to this letter. That arrangement has been accepted also by Indian Trans-Continental Airways, Limited, in so far as they are concerned with through passages into and out of India^ including Burma. The main features of the arrangement are :— (1) The rebate allowed by the Companies will be of two kinds, viz. :— (i) a deferred rebate on a sliding scale from 1 per cent, to 5 percent, according to the aggregate annual ' money value ' of all ' concession ' and 4 duty ' passages booked with the Com panies. The amount in respect of each passage, which will be taken into account in calculating the deferred rebate, will be the tariff cost of the passage less any excess over the amount paid by Government which may be paid by the officer concerned from his own pocket, and any rebate granted bj^ the Companies to the officer or to Government at the time of booking; and (ii) a rebate of 10 per cent of the tariff cost on all duty passages. The term ' duty passage ' is to cover all passages, other than con cession passages, which are booked whether for officials or non-officials at Government expense. 692(0) FD2 The former rebate, i.e., the deferred rebate, will be claimed in England annually in arrears through the agency of the Accountant- General, India Office. Quarterly statements of passages paid for wholly or partly by Government will be sent to him for the purpose, separate statements being prepared for concession and duty passages. The latter kind of rebate, i .e., the 10 per cent, rebate, will be claimed at the time of making payment to the Companies. (2) Concession passages will be booked with the Companies either direct or through their accredited agents, and duty passages will be booked direct with the Companies. The procedure for the booking of concession passages will be the same as at present obtaining in the case of such passages taken by sea, i .e., they will be booked on the authority of a certificate of eligibility obtained from the audit officer concerned. The Company or their accredited agents, as the case may be, will present their bill for payment to that audit officer supported by the certificate issued by him. Duty passages will be booked by the head of the administrative Department concerned. The Company will forward their bill to that authority who in turn will forward it to the audit officer concerned for making payment to the Company. (3) If in any special case an officer is allowed to pay for a duty passage from his own pocket and to claim the cost thereof (within the limit admissible) subsequently from Government, he will be required, in order to enable Government to secure the defer red rebate thereon, to book his passage with the Company either direct or through their accredited agents, and to furnish the Company, at the time of booking, with a copy of the orders of the competent authority allowing him a free passage at Govern ment expense, so that they may be able to trace the passage when the rebate statement in which it is included is received by them. He will also be required to furnish the particulars of the passage booked by him {i .e., the name of the Company and the aeroplane, the date of embarkation, the tariff cost of the passage and the amount actually borne by Government and the agency through which the passage has been booked) to the audit officer concerned for the purpose of the quarterly statements to be forwarded to the Accountant-General, India Office. The audit officer will support the claim for rebate in respect of such a passage by a certificate from himself to the effect that Government accepts the liability for the cost or part cost of the passage. ^4) The arrangement is taking effect from the 1st January 1934, and the rebate-year in regard to air passages will be the calendar year running from 1st January to 31st December. 2. All audit officers are being requested to prepare claims for the rabates in respect of passages booked during the year 1934 for transmission to the Accountant-General. India Office, at as early a date as possible. The claims will be forwarded to him on the civil side by the Accountant-General, Central Revenues, and on the military side by the Military Accountant-General. 3. A list of accredited agents on behalf of both Imperial Airways, Limited and Indian Trans-Continental Airways, Limited, is enclosed. 4. I am to add that the 10 per cent, rebate will be allowed by Imperial Airways, Limited, and Indian Trans-Continental Airways, Limited, on ** concession ' passages to Government servants. The Government servant will draw on his passage account up to the credit admissible for the journey performed and pay the balance out of his own pocket. The amount to be so paid will be reduced by a 10 per cent, rebate over the whole cost of the passage. Government will not be concerned with this part of the transactionbut will include the amount paid to the Government servant from the passage account in the claim to the deferred rebate which it has been agreed that Imperial Airways and Indian Trans-Continental Airways, Limited, shall give to Government. I have the honour to be, S ir, Your most obedient servant, W. CHRISTIE, Deputy Secretary to the Government of India. No. F. 4(17)-R. I./34. As regards the points raised in your letters under reply, it will be seen that— (1) Government is to get deferred rebate only on the net fare payable by Government for all passages booked under the scheme—see paragraph 8 of the memorandum of procedure. (2) Provision has been made for cases in which an officer is allowed to pay for a passage from his own pocket and to claim the cost (within the limit admissible) subsequently from Govern ment-—see paragraph 9 of the memorandum of procedure. For this purpose such passages must, however, in all cases, be booked either with the Company direct or with an accredited Agent of the Company. (3) Duty passages are intended to include all ordinary Government passages, as distinct from concession passages, whether taken for officials or non-officials. (4) The special rebate of 10 per cent, on passages booked direct by Government is to be claimed at the time of making payment to the Company in respect of the passage or passaged concerned —see 2 >aragraph 3 of memorandum of procedure. In any cases which may arise in which a portion of the cost is borne by the Government servant himself, it is not intended that the rebate shall be shared with such servant but that it will accrue wholly to Government. (5) The Guaranteed Indian Railway Companies, and also the Bengal and North-Western and Rohilkund and Kumaon Railway Companies to a limited extent, have been included in the rebate arrangement—see paragraph 10 of memorandum of procedure. 4. The statement of procedure is in the main self-explanatory but special attention is drawn to the following points, viz.— (a) The procedure indicated in paragraph 7 regarding passages where adjustments arise differs from that which applies in the case of rebate claimable in respect of sea passages. (6) In order to ensure that rebate will be claimable on all concession passages booked by officers, it is desirable that air concession certificates when issued should bear an instruction requiring the holder to book direct with Imperial Airways or with an accredited Agent of that Company. (c) The rebate scheme is not limited in its application to passages between India and the United Kingdom but covers in addition disbursements for passages by Imperial Airways such as those for Conference delegates proceeding by air between the United Kingdom and the Continent. Passages from one part of India to another are however outside its scope. [d) The form of return is that intended to be used for the submission of the annual claims to Imperial Airways Limited. The form will require modification as and when necessary to meet the requirements for furnishing the periodical returns to the Ac- countant-General at this Office. I am. As already agreed, the rebate arrangement comes into force with effect from 1st January 1934. 2. The arrangement provides for a deferred rebate on the money value of passages provided by Government for officials and non-officials travelling on duty and of concession passages provided under Government rules for officers of the Indian Services and for their families on the following scale, such rebate to be calculated annually in arrear :— 1 per cent on passages of an aggregate money less than £4,000. value of £2,000 and 2 per cent on passages of an aggregate money less than £6,000. value of £4,000 and 3 per cent on passages of an aggregate money less than £8,000. value of £6,000 and 4 per cent on passages of an aggregate money less than £10,000. value of £8,000 and 5 per cent on passages of an aggregate money value of £10,000 and o\er. 3. Duty passages will be booked by Government direct with the Com pany. A 10 per cent, rebate on the published fares will also be allowed to Government on such passages and will be claimed at the time of booking. 4. An officer applying for a concession passage by air will be furnished with a certificate from Government (issued in India by the Audit Officers and in England by the High Commissioner for India in the case of civil officers and by the Military Secretary, India Office, in the case of Military officers) which he will present to the Company, either direct or through accredited Agents, and if the cost of any passage engaged by him exceeds the amount entered in the certificate, the difference must be paid by the officer himself. 5. The certificate so supplied will be evidence that the passage is required for the purposes of Government. 6. Claims for deferred rebate on both duty and concession passages will be collected, prepared and submitted annually to the Company by the Accountant-General, India Office, supported by statements {vide attached specimen), the number and date of the bill on which payment was made to the Company being shown against each entry in the statements. 7. Claims for rebate will be preferred as soon as possible after the close of the calendar year and any adjusting payments or refunds made in respect of passages taken in a previous year will be included in the annual statement for the year in which the adjustment is made. 8. The ' money value ' on which the deferred rebate is to be calculated will be taken in each case as the tariff rate at the time of booking of the parti cular passage or passages concerned, less any excess over the certificate value which may be paid by the officer and any rebate granted by the Company to the officer or to Government at the time of booking. 9. In any individual case in which an officer is allowed to pay for a passage from his own pocket and to claim the cost* subsequently from Government, particulars of the passage so booked will be ascertained from him and entered in the statement to be submitted to the Company. The Company will be informed at the time that Government accepts liability for the passage. In all such cases the passage concerned must have been booked with the Company direct or with an accredited Agent of the Company. 10. The scheme will apply in its entirety to passages by air provided by the Guaranteed Indian Railway Companies for their officers. Subject: Joining time on first appointment to officers recruited overseas. —r-r ill* • • • • I am directed to refer to the India Office letter No. S&G 906/32 dated the 21st i-arch 1932 ladOressed to the Government of ^-ndia in the finance department} intimating in t er alia the concurrence of the secretary of State in Council in the definition which the Grovemment of India proposed to apply to the phrase 'without avoidable delay' occurring in the Finance Department letter No.7/XX-E.I/28, dated the 19th May 1923, which is 'based on the orders con tained in the late Lord Birkenhead's despatch No. 9-3ervices, dated the 23rd .February 1928. 2. in connection with a recent case, the question has^ arisen whether the term 'without avoidable delay' refers only to delay on the part of tl e officer in joining his first appointment or also to delay caused hy a local Government deferring tbe issue of posting orders either inadvertantly or deliberately. The orders issued in 1932 hrse hitherto been i eld to apply to both classes of case^, but on re-examining the matter, the Government of India are now inclined to think that this is not consistent with the original orders of the Secretary of ^tate, as in a case v;here the local Government delays posting orders, the delay in joining his first appointment is not the fault of the ofiicer and there is consequenlly no question of it being a delay which he could avoid. Oncd a newly appointed officer reports to his local Government he is under their control and it is for them to direct his movements. If they do not give him orders promptly as to his ultimate station, he-2- should not 'be penalised. Such delays can 'be dealt with 'by local Governments themselves under the ^ower ves ted in them 'by i^ndamental Rule 9(6) ('b) (iv) and tfee present interpretation of the Secretary of State's orders is inconsistent with that rule as involving in terference 'by him with the power delegated to local Governments. 3. The Government of India therefore propose to define the term 'without avoidable delay 1 * as refaa ring only to delay on the part of the officer in reporting himself for duty (either at the loccl Government's he^dauarters or at the actual ;.lace of duty, as the case may he) and not to delay in actually taking up his duties thereafter. I am to request that the orders of the oec etary of 3tate in Council may he obtained on this point and communicated to the Government of India. NOTIFICATION. \. *u * -a' Public. .Wew Delhi, the. 24th December 1935, No. F. 50/20/34. —The following reso lution by the Secretary of State for India in Council is published for general information: — In exercise of the powers conferred by sub section 2 of section 96B of the Government cf India Act and in pursuance of Kules 47 and 43 (a) of the Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, the Secretary of State for India in Council, with the concur rence of a majority of votes at a meeting of the Council of India held the 13th day of August 1935, has made the following rules: — 1. Title. —These rules may be called the Government Servants' Conduct Rules, 1935. 2. Definitione. —In these rules: — (1) 'government servant' means— (a) a member of an All-India Service, of the Indian Political Department, or of the Indian Ecclesiastical Establish ment, or (b) an officer holding the King's Commis sion on the active list of the Regular Army, the Royal Air Force or the Royal Indian Navy and serving in a Central, Provincial or Specialist Ser vice, whether for the time being on foreign service or not, but does not include such member or officer as aforesaid when holding the office of Governor of a Province, of Member of the Executive Council of the Governor General or of a Governor, or of Judge of a High Court; (2) 'Indian' means a person of unmixed Asiatic descent permanently resident in India; 4ind (3) 'Local Government' means— (a) the Local Government of a Governor 's Province in respect of government servants under the administrative . - - control of such Local Government and in respect of matters relating to asso ciations the membership of which is confined to such government servants, and ■(h) the Governor General in Council in respect of government servants, and - matters relating to associations, other than those referred to in. clause (a): : >1 •i'i jifOitt'SC UVivfo i .4 . • vlu £•. . .V ,.-J ci.-l 'j 7 '■ {'.} .«•<;>•*.-tj-. JXu Provided that ,a Local Government may, by general or special order, and subject to such conditions as it may think fit, declare any authority sub ordinate to it to be the Local Govern ment for all or any of the purposes of these rules: Provided further that the Auditor General shall exercise the powers of a local Government under these rules in respect of officers of the Indian Audit and Accounts Service who are mem bers of the Indian Civil Service. 3. Oifts, gratuities and rewards. —(1) Save as otherwise provided in this rule, no govern ment servant shall, except with the previous sanction of the local Government— (a) accept directly or indirectly on his own behalf or on behalf of any other * person, or (b) permit any member of his family so to accept, any gift, gratuity or reward or any offer of a gift, gratuity, or reward from an Indian who is not related to him. (2) A Political Officer may accept a ceremo nial gift from the Prince or Chief of a State in India if the gift is such that a return gift will be made at the expense of Government. A gift so accepted shall be delivered to the Local Government. (3) Subject to the provisions of any general or special order of the Local Government, a government servant may accept from any Indian a complimentary gift of flowers or fruit or similar articles of trifling value, but all Gov ernment servants shall use their best en deavours to discourage the tender of such gifts. (4) Subject to the provisions of any general or special order of the Local Government, a government servant may accept, or permit any member of his family to accept, from an Indian who is his personal friend, a wedding gift of a value which is reasonable in all the circums tances of the case, and which, in the case of a wedding gift offered to a European government servant or to a member of his family, does not exceed Rs. 200. All government servants shall use their best endeavours to discourage the tender of such gifts and such acceptance 'jr permission shall be reported to the Local Gov ernment, and, if the Local Government so requires, the gift shall be returned to the donor. (5) If a government servant cannot, without giving undue offence, refuse a gift of substantial value from an Indian, he may accept the same, but shall, unless the Local Government by special order otherwise directs, deliver the gift to the Local Government. (6) Subject to the provisions of any rules made by the Secretary of State in Council and, of any special or general orders of the Local Government not repugnant to such rules, a medical officer may accept any gift, gratuity or reward offered in good faith by any person or body of persons in recognition of his professional services.,4. Public demonatrationa in honour of govern ment servants. —(1) Save as otherwise provided ^ thia rule, no government servant shall, except ( with the previous sanction of the Local Gov- (ernment— (lo) receive any complimentary or valedic tory address, accept any testimonial or attend any public meeting or enter tainment held in his honour; or (6) take part in the presentation of a complimentary or valedictory address or of a testimonial to any other govern ment servant or to any person who has recently quitted the service of Govern ment, or attend a public meeting or entertainment held in honour of such other government servant or person. (2) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-rule (1)— (а) a Chief Commissioner may receive an address; (б) a government servant may at the request of any public body sit for a portrait, bust or statue not intended for presentation to him; (c) subject to the provisions of any general or special order of the Local Govt., a government servant may take part in the raising of a fund to be expended, in recognition of the services of any other government servant or of a person who has recently quitted the service of Government, on the foundation of a scholarship or on any other public or charitable object or on the execution of any portrait, bust or statue not intended for presentation to such other government servant or person; Provided that no government servant shall solicit any subscription in aid of such fund; {d) subject to the provisions of any general or special order of the Local Govern ment, a government servant may attend a farewell entertainment of a substantially private and informal character held as a mark of regard to himself or to any other government servant, or to a person who has recently quitted the service of Govern ment, on the occasion of the retire ment from the service or departure from a district or station of himself or such other government servant or person. 5. Presentation of trowels, etc., at cere monial functions. —(1) No government servant shall, except with the previous sanction of the Local Government, receive any trowel, key or other similar article offered to him at a cere monial function, such as the laying of a founda tion stone or the opening of a public building. (2) Nothing in sub-rule (1) shall apply to a Chief Commissioner, to a Resident of the First Class, to the Commissioner in Sind, to a member of a Board of Revenue, to a Financial Commissioner, to a Resident of the Second Class or to a Commissioner of a Division. 6. Subscriptions. —No government servant shall, except with the previous sanction of the Local Government, ask for or accept from a Prince or Chief of any State in India, or th» Agent of any such Prince or Chief, any sub scription or other pecuniary assistance in pursu ance of any object whatsoever. 7. Lending and Borrowing. —(1) No govern ment servant shall lend money to any person possessing land within the local limits of hi» authority, or, except in the ordinary course of business with a bank or firm of standing, borrow money from, or otherwise place himself under a pecuniary obligation to, any person subject to his official authority, or residing^ possessing immovable property or carrying on .business within the local limits of such autho rity: Provided that this sub-rule shall, in its appli cation to the dealings of a government servant with a Co-operative Society registered under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1912 (II of 1912),. or under any Provincial Co-operative Societies Act, be subject to such relaxation as the Local Government may by special or general order direct. (2) When a government servant is appointed or transferred to a post of such a nature that a person from whom he has borrowed money or to whom he has otherwise placed himself under a pecuniary obligation will be subject to his. official authority, or will reside, possess immo vable property or carry on business within the local limits of such authority, he shall forth with report the circumstances to the Local Government, and shall thereafter act m accord ance with such orders as may be passed by the Local Government. 8. Buying and selling houses and other valu able property. —Save in the case of a transac tion conducted in good faith with a regular dealer or permitted under Rule 9, a govern ment servant who intends to transact any pur chase, sale or disposal by other means of movable or immovable property exceeding in value Rs. 200 with an Indian residing, possess ing immovable property or carrying on business within the local limits of the official authority of such government servant, shall declare his intention to the Local Government. The decla ration shall state fully the circumstances, the price offered or demanded and, in the case of disposal otherwise than by sale, the method of disposal, and the government servant shall thereafter act in accordance with such orders as may be passed by the Local Government: Provided that a government servant who is about to quit the local limits of his official authority may, without reference to the Local Government, dispose of any of his movable pro perty by circulating lists of it among the public generally or by causing it to be sold by public auction. 9. Holding or acquiring immovable property. —(1) No government servant domiciled outside Asia shall, save in good faith for the purpose of residence, directly or indirectly hold or acquire immovable property— (a) within the province in which he is em ployed or within any province with the* administration of which he is con cerned or within a State in India in. which be is employed; or3 (b) within, any other province, except with the previous sanction of the Local Government; or (c) within any other State in India, except with the previous sanction of the Gov ernor-General in Council. (2) No government servant domiciled in Asia shall, save in good faith for the purpose of resi dence, acquire any immovable property in India by purchase or gift, except with the pre vious sanction of the Local Government. 10. Control over immovable property held or acquired by government servants. —Subject to the provisions of any general or special order of the Local Government, every government ser vant or candidate for Government service shall make to the Government concerned, through the usual channel, a declaration of all immo vable property in India from time to time held or acquired by him or by his wife or by any member of his family living with, or in any way dependent upon, him. The declaration shall state the district or the State in India within which the property is situated and shall contain such further information as the Local Government may by general or special order require. 11. Investments. —(1) No government ser vant shall speculate in investments. For the purposes of this sub-rule, the habitual purchase and sale of securities of notoriously fluctuating value shall be deemed to be speculation in in vestments, (2) No government servant shall make any investment likely to embarrass or influence him in the discharge of his official duties. (3) If any question arises whether a security or an investment is of the nature referred to in sub-rule (1) or sub-rule (2) respectively, the decision of the Local Government thereon shall be final. 12. Promotion and Management of Com panies. —No government servant shall, except with the previous sanction of the Secretary of State in Council, take part in the promotion, registration or management of any bank or com pany : Provided that a government servant may, \\ith the previous sanction of the Governor-General in Council, enter into the service of a railway company: Provided also that a government servant may, in accordance with the provisions of any general or special order of the Local Govern ment, take part in the promotion, registration or management of a Co-operative Society regis tered under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1912 (II of 1912), or under any Provincial Co operative Societies Act. 13. Private trade or employment. —No govern ment servant shall, except with the previous sanction of the Local Government, engage in any trade or undertake any employment or work, other than his official duties: Provided that a government servant may, without such sanction, undertake honorary work of a social or charitable nature or occasional work of a literary or artistic character, subject to the condition that his official duties do not thereby suffer; but he shall not undertake, or shall discontinue, such work if so directed by the Local Government. 14. Insolvency and habitual indebtedness.— A government servant shall avoid habi tual indebtedness. If a government servant is adjudged or declared insolvent, or if a moiety of his salary is frequently attached for debt, has been continuously so attached for a period exceeding two years, or is attached for a sum which, in ordinary circumstances, he could not repay within a period of two years, he may, unless he proves that the insolvency or indebted ness is the result of circumstances which, with the exercise of ordinary diligence, he could not have foreseen or over which he had no control, and has not proceeded from extragavant or dis sipated habits, be presumed to have contravened this rule. A government servant who applies to be or is adjudged or declared insolvent shall forthwith report his insolvency to the head of the office or department in which he is em ployed. 15. Communication of official documents or information. —No government servant shall, except in accordance with any special or general order of the Local Government, communicate, directly or indirectly, any official document or information to a government servant unautho rised to receive the same, to a non-official per son, Or to the Press. 16. Connection with Press. —No government servant shall, except with, and during the conti nuance of, the previous sanction of the Local Government, own in whole or in part, or con duct or participate in the editing or manage ment of any newspaper or other periodical publication. 17. Anonymous publication of docuvients and anonymous communications to the Press. —No government servant shall, in any document which he publishes anonymously or in any anonymous communication to the Press, criti cise the policy or action of Government intem- perately or unreasonably. A government servant shall in respect of any such publication or com munication be subject to the provisions of R u I q. 15. 18. Publication of documents and communis cations to the Press in the name of (iovemmcnt servants and public speeches. —(1) No govern ment servant shall, in any document published, under his own name or in any communicationj made to the Press under his own name or in any public utterance delivered by him, make any statement of fact or opinion which ifii capable of embarrassing— (а) the relations between the Governor- General in Council or any Local Gov ernment and the people of India or any section thereof, or * (б) the relations between His Majesty's Government or the Governor-General in Council and any foreign country or the Prince or Chief of any State in India. (2) A government servant who intends to publish any document under his own name or to make any communication to the Press under his own name or to deliver any public utterancecontaining statements in respect of which any doubt to the application ot the restrictions imposed by sub-rule (1) may arise shall submit to the Local Government a copy or draft of the document which he intends to publish or of the utterance which he intends to deliver,' and shall thereafter act in accordance with such Orders as may be passed by the Local Govern ment. 19. Evidence before Committees. —(1) No government servant shall give evidence before a public committee— (а) in India, except with the previous sanction of the Local Government; (б) Outside India, except with the previ ous sanction of the Secretary of State in Council. <3--» - (2) No government servant giving such evi dence shall criticise the policy or decisions of the Secretary of State, of the Governor- General in Council or of any Local Govern ment. (3) This rule shall not apply to evidence given before statutory committees which have power to compel attendance and the giving of answers, nor to evidence given in judicial in quiries. 20. Talcing part in politics and elections.— (1) (i) Subject to any general or special order of the Local Government, no government ser vant shall take part in, subscribe in aid of, or tissist in any way any political movement in India, or relating to Indian affairs. Explanation. —The expression 'political movement' includes any movement or acti vities tending directly or indirectly to excite disaffection against, or to embarrass, the Gov ernment as by law established, or to promote feelings of hatred or enmity between different classes of His Majesty's subjects, or to disturb the public peace. (ii) No government servant shall permit any person dependent on him for maintenance or under his care or control to take part in, or m any way assist, any movement or activity which is, or tends directly or indirect ly to be, subversive of Government as by law established in India. Explanation. —A government servant shall be deemed to have permitted a person to take part in or assist a movement or activity within the meaning of clause (ii) if he has not taken every possible precaution and done everything in his power to prevent such person so acting, or if, when he knows or has reason to suspect that such person is so acting, he does not at once inform the Local Government or the officer to whom he is subordinate. (2) No government servant shall canvas or •otherwise interfere or use his influence in con nection with, or take part in, any election to a legislative body, whether in India or elsewhere: Provided that a government servant who is qualified to vote at such election may exercise his right to vote; but, if he does so, shall give no indication of the manner in which, he pro poses to vote or has voted. .. -• J -I. I'. * 0;* (3) A government servant who issues an address to electors or in any other manner pub licly announces himself or allows himself to be publicly announced as a candidate or prosper tive candidate for election to a legislative body shall be deemed for the purposes of sub-rule (2) to take part in an election to such body. c . / (4) The provisions of sub-rules (2) and (3) shall, so far as may be, apply to elections to local authorities or bodies, save in respect of government servants required or permitted by or under any law, or order of Government, for the time being in force to be a candidate at' such elections. 21. Vindication of acts and character of gov ernment servants as such. —(1) No government servant shall, except with the previous sanction of the Local Government, have recourse to any Court or the Press for the vindication of his official acts or character from defamatory attacks. (2) Nothing in sub-rule (1) shall derogate from the right of a government servant to vindicate his private acts or character. 22. Membership of Service Associations.— No government servant shall be a member, representative or officer of any association re presenting, or purporting to represent, govern ment servants or any class of government ser vants unless such association satisfies the following conditions, namely: — (а) Membership of the association shall be confined to a distinct class of govern ment servants, and shall be open to all government servants of that class; (б) The association shall not be in any way connected with, or affiliated to— (i) any association which does not, or (ii) any federation of associations which do not, satisfy condition (a); (c) the association shall not be in any way connected with any political party or organisation, or engage in any political activity; • (d) the association shall not— (i) issue or maintain any periodical publication except in accordance with any general or special order of the Local Government; (ii) except with the previous banction of the Local Government, publish any representation on behalf of its mem bers. whether in the Press or other wise;( 5 r (iii) in respect of any election to a legis lative body, whether in India or elsewhere, or to a local authority or body— (A) pay, or contribute towards, auy expenses incurred in connection with his candidature by a candi date for such election; (B) by any means support the candida ture of any person for such election; or (G) undertake or assist in the registra tion of electors, or the selection of a candidate for such election; (iv) maintain or contribute towards the maintenance of any member of a legislative body, whether in India or elsewhere, or of any member of a local authority or body; or (v) pay, or contribute towards, the ex penses of any Trade Union which has constituted a fund under sec tion 16 of the Indian Trade Unions Act, 192G (XVI of 1926); Provided that conditions (a) and {b) shall not be held to debar any government servant from remaining or becoming a member of the European Government Servants' Association or the Indian Officers' Association and that the Local Government may, for reasons to be recorded in writing, by general or special order, dispense with those conditions in the case of any other association. 23. Control of government servants outside India. —The Secretary of State in Council shall, for the purposes of these rules, be deemed to be the Governor-General in Council or the Local Government, as the case may be, in respect of a government servant who is on leave, or on duty, outside India. 24. Saving. —Nothing in these rules shall be deemed to derogate from the provisions of any law, or of any order of any competent author ity, for the time being in force, relating to the conduct of government servants. 25. Repeal. —The Government Servants' Conduct Eules are hereby superseded in respect of government servants to whom these rules apply. J. A. THORNE. Addl. Joint Secy, to the Govt, of India. physicalDescription.extent: File papers are arranged chronologically, according to the date they were circulated to the Political Agent, Bahrain and others. They are followed by file notes (folios 282-289) which consist mainly of a list of most documents in the file, together with their unique document reference number to help identify them. The list usually records both the folio number, prefixed by the letter 'p' for page (e.g. p81) and the simple reference number from 1 to 86, which has been written on many documents, usually the circulation slips, mainly in red crayon and encircled. The pencilled folio numbers and the red document numbers help to locate specific documents in the file.

Foliation: numbered 1A-1B, 2-76, 77A, 77B, 78-86, 87A, 87B, 88-122, 124-147, 149, 150, 152, 154-170, 172-189, 191-193, 195, 197-290. The number 69 has been omitted. Folios 122, 147, 150, 152, 170, 189, 193, 195 have been additionally numbered 123, 148, 151, 153, 171, 190, 194 and 196 respectively on the verso. The numbering is written in pencil in the top right corner of the folio, starting at the front of the file, on the file cover (f 1A) and ending on the inside cover at the back of the file (f 290).

mods.abstract: The file contains Government of India circular letters, memoranda and notices issued mainly by the Finance Department and the Home Department. These were regularly forwarded by the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire to the Political Agent, Bahrain and others for information and guidance. The circulars contain rules, procedures and instructions that relate to a wide range of personnel matters, including: the type, number and grading of government posts and their rates of pay, leave allowance and leave salary, pensions, travelling allowance and travel expenses. Typical file contents are:Finance Department notifications containing amendments to the Fundamental Rules, Superior Civil service Rules, Revised Leave Rules 1933, Civil Service Regulations, Pay and Cadre Schedules;Circular letters exchanged between the Government of India Finance Department and the India Office, Financial Department, London in 1935, regarding the interpretation and amendment of Fundamental Rule 83 in relation to the leave salary entitlement of officers on special disability leave;Home Department notifications containing the new Government Servants' Conduct Rules 1935, amendments to the schedule listing the type and number of posts in various Government departments, amendments to the schedule annexed to the Revised Rates of Pay Rules, procedures to be followed in staff disciplinary proceedings.
